key_title: Key to the species of Doodia

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Pinnae sessile, bases flanged, except for an isolated pair of shortly stalked pinnae at base (which may be absent in some specimens); stipe and rachis rough, with black scales
Pinnae in lower part of lamina shortly stalked or with basal margins approaching midvein at least on upper side, separate
Pinnae stalked in lower half of lamina; fertile fronds longer and more erect than sterile ones; stipe and rachis generally smooth

Pinnae stalked for less than lower one-third of lamina (pinnae bases in middle region of lamina may be narrowed (more so on upper side) but not stalked); fertile fronds similar to sterile ones or else (when growing among rocks) longer and with pinnae more separated; stipe and rachis moderately rough and tuberculate
